item.title: MPI Traffic Program with C++
item.description: I want to solve a traffic problem with MPI and C++. The road is divided into sections which send their boundaries and receive their ghost points.

item.title: Debug MPI program with Visual Studio Code
item.description: Debugging MPI program can be a nightmare. I explain how easily you can debug a parallel MPI program with visual studio (VS) code.

item.title: C++ auto makes your life easier
item.description: In C++, auto keyword can speed up coding and improve the maintainability of code. Here, I show cases that auto can make a difference.

item.title: MPI race condition
item.description: When a buffer, which is involved in an uncompleted non-blocking communication, is used in another communication, there will be a race to read and write the buffer.

item.title: MPI ping pong program using C++
item.description: I want to write an MPI ping pong program where two processes send a piece of data back and forth to each other.

item.title: How and where to use C++ templates
item.description: Using templates in C++, you can create functions or classes having similar behaviors for different types. Here, all the useful features of templates are explained with examples.

item.title: C++ inheritance crash course
item.description: Inheritance is the mechanism that the attributes and methods of a base class are passed to a derived class. Here, all useful details of C++ inheritance are mentioned with examples.

item.title: What is a recursive function?
item.description: Definition A recursive function is a function that calls itself with different arguments. Therefore, it is applied to a problem that each step of it is similar to the previous one.

item.title: What is "object slicing" trap in C++?
item.description: Every now and then, I switch programming language from C# to C++, I fall in the trap of object slicing. It happens when a derived object is assigned by value to a base object where the extra information in the derived object is scrapped for worst.

item.title: How to use C/C++ raw pointers properly?
item.description: A pointer is an 8-byte type on a 64-bit machine that holds the memory address of an object, target. Here, I mention the most useful characteristics of pointers with examples.
